case.name: Carey v Australian Securities and Investments Commission [2008] FCA 963 (26 June 2008)

citphrases.citphrase: whether ceo of the commission had power under s 59(7) of the australian crime commission act 2002 (cth) to disclose that information to the australian taxation office
meaning of 'law enforcement agency' for the purposes of the act
whether australian crime commission has power to disclose that information to the australian taxation office

administrative decisions judicial review legislation -application for review of decision that it is in the "public interest" to cause proceedings to be begun and carried on against the applicant pursuant to section 50 of the australian securities commission act 1989 , as distinct from decision to begin and carry on the proceedings
whether former decision a "decision" within the meaning of the administrative decisions (judicial review) act 1977
whether applicant "aggrieved" by the decision. administrative law
whether decision an improper exercise of the power conferred by section 50 of the australian securities commission act 1989
whether decision involved a failure to take into account relevant considerations
whether decision involved the taking into account of irrelevant considerations
error of law. words and phrases
action by regulator in name of corporation
action brought pursuant to statutory power
whether any risk of dissipation of assets
liberty to apply at short notice to vary or discharge restraint.

citances.sentence: 2 These proceedings were commenced following a decision by Finkelstein J in judicial review proceedings in Carey v Australian Securities and Investments Commission, VID57 of 2008, that ASIC was not authorised under s 50 of the ASIC Act to cause previous Federal Court proceedings, VID 351 of 2007, brought in the name of the company in liquidation, and existing Federal Court proceedings, VID 386 of 2007, to be carried on by it in the name of Ann Street: Carey v Australian Securities and Investments Commission [2008] FCA 963.
